title: Top Spiking Technical Analysis Articles This Week

text:
Equity markets were up overall this past week, and the S&P 500 notably crossed above its 200-day moving average for the first time since March. Still, ongoing market volatility has remained, producing wide price swings that have continued to spook investors. This volatile market environment has prevailed on and off for more than three months as the economic effects of the global coronavirus pandemic continue to reverberate.

While longer-term investors may have a strong aversion to the exaggerated market moves that have been the rule of late, shorter-term traders tend to prefer them. Larger price moves provide more potential opportunities for short-term profits (as well as for losses). In fact, we've seen trading volumes soar during the current economic crisis as experienced traders become even more active and new traders open brokerage accounts in droves.

For such shorter-term traders, technical analysis remains the overwhelmingly preferred trading strategy. Technical analysis is a comprehensive body of knowledge and set of tools meant to identify trading opportunities through the analysis of price movement, trading volume, chart patterns, and mathematical indicators.

Here at Investopedia, we've seen reader interest in technical analysis topics spike sharply throughout the past several weeks and months. This past week, readers were especially interested in candlestick charts and patterns—the Japanese style of charting that has become the preferred method of visual price interpretation for traders and investors around the world.

Here are some of the top spiking technical analysis articles this week:

Candlestick charts originated in Japan over 100 years before the West developed the bar and point-and-figure charts. Candlesticks visually represent price moves with different colors and structural elements. Traders use the candlesticks to make trading decisions based on regularly occurring patterns that help forecast the short-term direction of the price.

Here's an example of one candlestick pattern—the bullish engulfing pattern—seen recently on a current daily chart of Tesla Inc. (TSLA):

Below is a current example of a three black crows pattern seen on a daily chart of Netflix Inc. (NFLX):

Bullish reversal patterns should form within a downtrend. Otherwise, it’s not a bullish pattern, but a continuation pattern. Most bullish reversal patterns require bullish confirmation. In other words, they must be followed by an upside price move.

Below is a current daily chart of Apple Inc. (AAPL) showing one of these bullish candlestick patterns—the hammer:

The term "hanging man" refers to the candle's shape, as well as what the appearance of this pattern infers. The hanging man represents a potential downside reversal in an uptrend.

<div id="mntl-sc-page_1-0" class="comp article-body-content mntl-sc-page mntl-block" data-sc-sticky-offset="80" data-sc-ad-label-height="0" data-sc-ad-track-spacing="90" data-sc-min-track-height="250" data-sc-max-track-height="600" data-sc-breakpoint="40em" data-sc-load-immediate="2" data-sc-content-positions="[300, 1, 1, 1250, 1, 1]" data-bind-scroll-on-start="true">
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0" class="comp mntl-sc-block finance-sc-block-html mntl-sc-block-html">
<p>Equity markets were up overall this past week, and the S&P 500 notably crossed above its 200-day moving average for the first time since March. Still, ongoing market <a href="https://www.investopedia.com/terms/v/volatility.asp" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="1">volatility</a> has remained, producing wide price swings that have continued to spook investors. This volatile market environment has prevailed on and off for more than three months as the economic effects of the global coronavirus pandemic continue to reverberate.</p>
</div>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-1" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-adslot mntl-block"></div>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-2" class="comp mntl-sc-block finance-sc-block-html mntl-sc-block-html">
<p>While longer-term investors may have a strong aversion to the exaggerated market moves that have been the rule of late, shorter-term traders tend to prefer them. Larger price moves provide more potential opportunities for short-term profits (as well as for losses). In fact, we've seen trading volumes soar during the current economic crisis as experienced traders become even more active and new traders open brokerage accounts in droves.</p>
</div>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-3" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-adslot mntl-block"></div>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-4" class="comp mntl-sc-block finance-sc-block-html mntl-sc-block-html">
<p>For such shorter-term traders, <a href="https://www.investopedia.com/terms/t/technicalanalysis.asp" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="1">technical analysis</a> remains the overwhelmingly preferred trading strategy. Technical analysis is a comprehensive body of knowledge and set of tools meant to identify trading opportunities through the analysis of price movement, <a href="https://www.investopedia.com/terms/v/volume.asp" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="2">trading volume</a>, <a href="https://www.investopedia.com/terms/p/pattern.asp" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="3">chart patterns</a>, and mathematical <a href="https://www.investopedia.com/terms/t/technicalindicator.asp" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="4">indicators</a>.</p>
</div>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-5" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-adslot mntl-block"></div>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-6" class="comp mntl-sc-block finance-sc-block-html mntl-sc-block-html">
<p>Here at Investopedia, we've seen reader interest in technical analysis topics spike sharply throughout the past several weeks and months. This past week, readers were especially interested in <a href="https://www.investopedia.com/terms/c/candlestick.asp" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="1">candlestick charts</a> and patterns—the Japanese style of charting that has become the preferred method of visual price interpretation for traders and investors around the world.</p>
</div>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-7" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-adslot mntl-block"></div>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-8" class="comp mntl-sc-block finance-sc-block-html mntl-sc-block-html">
<p>Here are some of the top spiking technical analysis articles this week:</p>
</div>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-9" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-adslot mntl-block"></div>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-10" class="comp mntl-sc-block finance-sc-block-iframe mntl-sc-block-iframe mntl-block">
<iframe id="mntl-sc-block-iframe__uri_1-0" class="comp lazyload mntl-sc-block-iframe__uri mntl-block" data-src="https://datawrapper.dwcdn.net/nb5OY/1/" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="false" title="Technical Analysis Articles Spiking This Week"></iframe>
</div>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-11" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-adslot mntl-block"></div>
<a class="heading-toc" id="understanding-a-candlestick-chart"></a> <h2 id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-12" class="comp mntl-sc-block finance-sc-block-heading mntl-sc-block-heading"> <a href="https://www.investopedia.com/trading/candlestick-charting-what-is-it/" class="mntl-sc-block-heading__link" >Understanding a Candlestick Chart</a> </h2>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-13" class="comp mntl-sc-block finance-sc-block-html mntl-sc-block-html">
<p>Candlestick charts originated in Japan over 100 years before the West developed the <a href="https://www.investopedia.com/terms/b/barchart.asp" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="1">bar</a> and <a href="https://www.investopedia.com/terms/p/pointandfigurechart.asp" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="2">point-and-figure</a> charts. Candlesticks visually represent price moves with different colors and structural elements. Traders use the candlesticks to make trading decisions based on regularly occurring patterns that help forecast the short-term direction of the price.</p>
</div>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-14" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-adslot mntl-block"></div>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-15" class="comp mntl-sc-block finance-sc-block-html mntl-sc-block-html">
<p>Here's an example of one candlestick pattern—the bullish engulfing pattern—seen recently on a current daily chart of Tesla Inc. (<a href="https://www.investopedia.com/markets/quote?tvwidgetsymbol=TSLA" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="1">TSLA</a>):</p>
</div>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-16" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-adslot mntl-block"></div>
<figure id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-17" class="comp inline-image mntl-sc-block finance-sc-block-image mntl-sc-block-image figure-landscape figure-high-res">

<a class="heading-toc" id="the-5-most-powerful-candlestick-patterns"></a> <h2 id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-18" class="comp mntl-sc-block finance-sc-block-heading mntl-sc-block-heading"> <a href="https://www.investopedia.com/articles/active-trading/092315/5-most-powerful-candlestick-patterns.asp" class="mntl-sc-block-heading__link" >The 5 Most Powerful Candlestick Patterns</a> </h2>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-19" class="comp mntl-sc-block finance-sc-block-html mntl-sc-block-html">
<p>Many traders can identify dozens of candlestick patterns and formations, which have colorful names like <a href="https://www.investopedia.com/terms/d/darkcloud.asp" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="1">bearish dark cloud cover</a>, <a href="https://www.investopedia.com/terms/e/eveningstar.asp" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="2">evening star</a> and <a href="https://www.investopedia.com/terms/t/three_black_crows.asp" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="3">three black crows</a>. In addition, single bar patterns including the <a href="https://www.investopedia.com/terms/d/doji.asp" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="4">doji</a> and <a href="https://www.investopedia.com/terms/h/hammer.asp" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="5">hammer</a> have been incorporated into dozens of long- and short-side <a href="https://www.investopedia.com/terms/t/trading-strategy.asp" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="6">trading strategies</a>. Five of the most powerful candlestick patterns can be found <a href="https://www.investopedia.com/articles/active-trading/092315/5-most-powerful-candlestick-patterns.asp" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="7">here</a>.</p>
</div>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-20" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-adslot mntl-block"></div>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-21" class="comp mntl-sc-block finance-sc-block-html mntl-sc-block-html">
<p>Below is a current example of a three black crows pattern seen on a daily chart of Netflix Inc. (<a href="https://www.investopedia.com/markets/quote?tvwidgetsymbol=NFLX" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="1">NFLX</a>):</p>
</div>

<a class="heading-toc" id="using-bullish-candlestick-patterns-to-buy-stocks"></a> <h2 id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-24" class="comp mntl-sc-block finance-sc-block-heading mntl-sc-block-heading"> <a href="https://www.investopedia.com/articles/active-trading/062315/using-bullish-candlestick-patterns-buy-stocks.asp" class="mntl-sc-block-heading__link" >Using Bullish Candlestick Patterns To Buy Stocks</a> </h2>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-25" class="comp mntl-sc-block finance-sc-block-html mntl-sc-block-html">
<p>Bullish <a href="https://www.investopedia.com/terms/r/reversal.asp" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="1">reversal</a> patterns should form within a downtrend. Otherwise, it’s not a bullish pattern, but a <a href="https://www.investopedia.com/terms/c/continuationpattern.asp" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="2">continuation pattern</a>. Most bullish reversal patterns require bullish confirmation<strong>.<em> </em></strong>In other words, they must be followed by an upside price move.</p>
</div>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-26" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-adslot mntl-block"></div>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-27" class="comp mntl-sc-block finance-sc-block-html mntl-sc-block-html">
<p>Below is a current daily chart of Apple Inc. (<a href="https://www.investopedia.com/markets/quote?tvwidgetsymbol=AAPL" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="1">AAPL</a>) showing one of these bullish candlestick patterns—the hammer:</p>
</div>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-28" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-adslot mntl-block"></div>
<figure id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-29" class="comp inline-image mntl-sc-block finance-sc-block-image mntl-sc-block-image figure-landscape figure-high-res">
<div class="figure-media">

<a class="heading-toc" id="understanding-the-hanging-man-candlestick-pattern"></a> <h2 id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-30" class="comp mntl-sc-block finance-sc-block-heading mntl-sc-block-heading"> <a href="https://www.investopedia.com/articles/active-trading/040914/understanding-hanging-man-optimistic-candlestick-pattern.asp" class="mntl-sc-block-heading__link" >Understanding the 'Hanging Man' Candlestick Pattern</a> </h2>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-31" class="comp mntl-sc-block finance-sc-block-html mntl-sc-block-html">
<p>The term "hanging man" refers to the candle's shape, as well as what the appearance of this pattern infers. The hanging man represents a potential downside <a href="https://www.investopedia.com/terms/r/reversal.asp" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="1">reversal</a> in an <a href="https://www.investopedia.com/terms/u/uptrend.asp" data-component="link" data-source="inlineLink" data-type="internalLink" data-ordinal="2">uptrend</a>.</p>
</div>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-32" class="comp mntl-sc-block mntl-sc-block-adslot mntl-block"></div>
<div id="mntl-sc-block_1-0-33" class="comp mntl-sc-block finance-sc-block-html mntl-sc-block-html">

><span class="link__wrapper">Swing Trading Definition and Tactics</span></a>
<div id="related-terms__description_1-0-1" class="comp related-terms__description mntl-text-block">

><span class="link__wrapper">Moving Average Convergence Divergence – MACD Definition</span></a>
<div id="related-terms__description_1-0-2" class="comp related-terms__description mntl-text-block">
Moving Average Convergence Divergence (MACD) is defined as a trend-following momentum indicator that shows the relationship between two moving averages of a security's price.</div>

><span class="link__wrapper">Fibonacci Retracement Levels</span></a>
<div id="related-terms__description_1-0-3" class="comp related-terms__description mntl-text-block">

><span class="link__wrapper">Moving Average (MA) Definition</span></a>
<div id="related-terms__description_1-0-4" class="comp related-terms__description mntl-text-block">
